column3: - Added a commit to properly stop other nodes, even when one fails to stop\n- Added a commit to update the Readme\n

Anyone interested in looking at the diff here? (It is mostly move-only and cleaning up the logic/ifelses)

It is already tested as part of #7972 but I'd prefer to have at least one read the patch.
@paveljanik Rebased, so the other doc changes are included as well.\n

I have a lot of these during tests, but not only in the PR - also applies to current master:

```
Running testscript wallet.py ...
Initializing test directory /var/folders/65/fn0h49r55k7779vg1b_h461r0000gn/T/testbv4onukz
Unexpected exception caught during testing: timeout('timed out',)
...
Running testscript abandonconflict.py ...
Initializing test directory /var/folders/65/fn0h49r55k7779v

It's just refactoring. Ideally, behavior should stay the same.

Also, I can't reproduce. Mind to open a issue for the timeouts?

utACK (feel free to ignore my ultranit)\n\nNot sure this needs to be addressed in this PR, but for supporting multiple tests running in parallel, I think it might make sense to add support to the test framework for specifying a range of ports to use for the p2p and rpc ports on the command line, which the `rpc_tests.py` script could use.  The logic now of hoping that pid's don't collide modulo som

Added a commit to fix @sdaftuar's nit, hopefully. In regard to the ports: I am wondering if it is sufficient to pass in a int `seed (default=pid)` instead of trying to parse ranges from the command line.\n
@marcofalke Yeah that approach of a single int that defaults to the pid sounds reasonable to me. Comment looks better too, thanks.\n
@theuni I am assuming this works fine on travis?\n
comment ultranit: the help is not actually the same for all scripts, as some tests take custom (optional) arguments.\n

This is true, but the previous behavior was to only show the help text of the first script and then `exit(0)`. If someone wants to change the behavior, I'd propose a separate pull. I am happy to change the comment in this pull, though.\n
